channel.title: Robot and image comparing
channel.description:
[s]Excuse the sarcastic title, but I seriously have no idea what its even called...[/s]
What I'm trying to do is having an image on my computer (lets say of a star) .. and now I am trying to compare this image to find a similar star on my screen. How would I do this? Or at least what is it called (so I can google)? I've tried searching with keywords like: pixel comparing picture screen finding area similar etc.
Closest thing to this I found was the getPixelColor(int x, int y) method in the robot class, but I think some of the runescape bot programmers used image compared (unless I am wrong and theres no such thing)
Thanks for your help in advance :)

item.title: Robot and image comparing
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“xeez`, post:6, topic:293876”]The method [tt]javax.imageio.ImageIO.read(File)[/tt] will return a “BufferedImage” instance, just like the method you are using to capture an image of the screen. So on both images, you can call [tt]getRGB(int, int)[/tt].

Yes, that is correct. Here are links to some documentations regarding the classes you are to use:

http://java.sun.com/javase/6/docs/api/java/awt/Robot.html
http://java.sun.com/javase/6/docs/api/javax/imageio/ImageIO.html
http://java.sun.com/javase/6/docs/api/java/awt/image/BufferedImage.html[/quote]

Or you could use ImageIcon. Some people may argue it’s easier to use, etc.

Read full topic

item.title: Robot and image comparing
item.dc:creator: @quest_rs quest rs
item.description:
@quest_rs wrote:

And speed does not matter, its just something personal… Making something to help out my dad with some web browsing related stuff…

I have the robot class, but thanks for the other two

Great! thanks for all your help once again.

Read full topic

item.title: Robot and image comparing
item.dc:creator: @xeez xeez`
item.description:
@xeez wrote:

The method [tt]javax.imageio.ImageIO.read(File)[/tt] will return a “BufferedImage” instance, just like the method you are using to capture an image of the screen. So on both images, you can call [tt]getRGB(int, int)[/tt].

Yes, that is correct. Here are links to some documentations regarding the classes you are to use:

http://java.sun.com/javase/6/docs/api/java/awt/Robot.html
http://java.sun.com/javase/6/docs/api/javax/imageio/ImageIO.html
http://java.sun.com/javase/6/docs/api/java/awt/image/BufferedImage.html

Read full topic

item.title: Robot and image comparing
item.dc:creator: @quest_rs quest rs
item.description:
@quest_rs wrote:

is there a method for getting the pixel’s rgb info for the image i load using javax.imageio.ImageIO.read(File)?

and thanks for your help I think now I have a path to do some research on this.

so as a summary, I load my image using javax.imageio.ImageIO.read(File), then buffer the screen and then read the pixels of the image to find the pattern and then look for that on the screen…is this correct?

Read full topic

item.title: Robot and image comparing
item.dc:creator: @xeez xeez`
item.description:
@xeez wrote:

You can load the image with the method: [tt]javax.imageio.ImageIO.read(File)[/tt]. Then, as I said, you compare the screen’s pixels with the image’s. This, of course, will provide a tremendously slow application; although I’m not sure if speed is what you are looking for.

EDIT: Since it looks like you want the program to constantly be comparing the screen’s image with your image, and want to develop something similar to “runescape color bots”, I suggest you get the window handle of the window you suspect that will draw the same image as yours (such as the runscape client with runescape color bots), and capture an image of that window. Of course, I’m not so sure that java provides such flexibility with window-handles in general. If this is the case, I’d suggest you use JNI for a (relatively) fast application.

Read full topic

item.title: Robot and image comparing
item.dc:creator: @quest_rs quest rs
item.description:
@quest_rs wrote:

but what if I already have the image in the program’s directory?

I know what my image looks like, its the screen I have to search on because I have to find the replica of the picture on the screen/page as it can change at any point. (or else i would’ve hardcoded mouseMove()<3)

I think what you’re telling me is how to get the screen correct? how do I load the image I am comparing with?

Read full topic

item.title: Robot and image comparing
item.dc:creator: @xeez xeez`
item.description:
@xeez wrote:

You can use Java’s Robot class to take a picture of the screen via [tt]java.awt.Robot.createScreenCapture(Rectangle)[/tt]. This method will return a BufferedImage. Once you have the two pictures (the screen, and your image) loaded as a ‘BufferedImage’ instance, you can compare the images pixel-by-pixel through [tt]java.awt.image.BufferedImage.getRGB(int, int)[/tt].

Have fun

Read full topic
